Executive Summary
Enerjisa √úretim A.S., a leading energy company, is dedicated to continuously developing its
knowledge base,settingindustrystandards,andshapingthefutureoftheenergysector.Asa
pioneering force in the industry, Enerjisa √úretim A.S. focuses on sustainable and innovative
energysolutions,contributingtothegrowthandstabilityoftheenergymarket.Thecompany
is committed to excellence and innovation, ensuring the delivery of reliable and efficient
energy to meet the evolving needs of society. Through its forward-thinking approach and
dedication to industry leadership, Enerjisa √úretim A.S. aims to create a sustainable and
prosperousfutureforall.
Enerjisa √úretim operates a range of power plants, including solar, hydroelectric, lignite,
combined cycle gas turbine(CCGT) and wind power facilities. The engineering activities
involve the design, operation, and optimization of these plants to ensure efficient and
reliable power production. Engineering efforts are dedicated to the maintenance and
upgrade of existing power generation facilities. This includes routineinspections,preventive
maintenance, and the implementation of technological upgrades to enhance performance
and extend the lifespan of equipment. The company engages in engineering projectsaimed
at improving energy efficiency across its operations. This includes the development and
implementation of advanced technologies andprocessestoreduceenergyconsumptionand
emissions.Engineering activities also focus on managing and mitigating environmental
impacts. This involves designing and implementing systems to control emissions, manage
waste,andcomplywithenvironmentalregulations.
Before the internship, it was expected that a foundational understanding of advanced
analytics techniques and their practical applications in the energy sector would be gained.
This included the effective utilization of analytical tools andprogramminglanguagessuchas
Python and Power BI to handle large datasets, develop optimization models, and generate
actionable insights. During the internship at Enerjisa √úretim A≈û, responsibilities within the
Advanced Analytics department primarily encompassed data analysis. This entailed the
meticulous gathering, processing, and interpretation of complex datasets to support the
company's strategic decision-making processes. Advanced analytical tools and techniques
were utilized, including Python libraries such as matplotlib, PuLP, pandas, seaborn, and
numpy, in addition to SQL for database managementanddataretrieval.Undertheguidance
of the team leader, three projects centered on Python in data analysis were assigned. A
significant part of the role involved maximizing asset valueandretrievingdataonpricesand
demand from EPIAS.OptimizationmodelsweredevelopedandimplementedinPythonusing
PuLP to identify the most efficient ways to allocate resources and enhance operational
performance. Through leveraging these tools, detailed visualizations are created, various
operational models are optimized, and comprehensive data manipulation and statistical
analysis are performed. These efforts contributed not only to optimizing operational
efficiencies and enhancing the overall performance of various projects but also provided
valuableinsightsforstrategicplanning.

1. Company and Sector
a. OverviewoftheCompanyandSector
Enerjisa √úretim Santralleri A.S., established in 1996, is a key player in the Turkish energy
generation sector. It operates under a joint venture between Sabancƒ± Holding, one of the
largest conglomerates in Turkey, and E.ON SE, a leading global energy provider based in
Germany[1]. The company primarily focuses on the generation of electricity from a mix of
natural gas, hydroelectric, domestic lignite, and renewable sources such as wind and solar.
Enerjisa √úretim's total installed capacity is approximately 3,813 megawatts (MW),
positioning it as a significant contributor to Turkey's energy sector. Its portfolio consists of
43% natural gas, 37% hydroelectric, 12% lignite, and 8% wind and solar energy [2]. The logo
ofEnerjisa√úretimA.S.isshowninFigure1.
Figure1.ThelogooftheEnerjisa√úretimA.S.[3].
Enerjisa √úretim is committed to increasing its renewable energy capacity, with ongoing
investments inwindandsolarpowerplants.Thecompanyaimstoreachaninstalledcapacity
of 5,000 MW by 2026, a goal that aligns with its strategy to reduce carbon emissions and
support Turkey's transition to renewable energy sources .Intermsofstructure,thecompany
operates various energy plants,including12hydroelectricplants,9windpowerplants,and2
solar power plants. Additionally,Enerjisa√úretimmanagesnaturalgasandlignite-firedpower
plants, contributing to a diversified energy production strategy . It has also set its sights on
new projects, such as the 150 MW hybrid solar power plant, which is expected to be
operational by the end of 2024 . Thecompanyemploysapproximately1,120individuals.This
workforce is composed of both blue-collar and white-collar professionals, including a
significantnumberofengineersandtechnicalexpertswhomanageoperations,maintenance,
andstrategicenergyprojects [2].TheportfoliooftheEnerjisa√úretimisshowninFigure2.
Figure2.TheportfoliooftheEnerjisa√úretim[3].
Enerjisa √úretim operates in a highly competitive sector, with keycompetitorsincludingAksa
Enerji, Zorlu Enerji, and Ayen Enerji. The company's maincustomersaredomesticelectricity

distributors and consumers, while it collaborates with both domestic and international
suppliers for the procurement of energy equipment and technology . As a leader in Turkey‚Äôs
renewable energy development, Enerjisa √úretim plays a crucial role in advancing the
country's energy independence andsustainabilityinitiatives.Itsstrategicfocusonrenewable
energy and the reduction of carbon emissions places the company at the forefront of
Turkey‚Äôs energy transformation . The mail address of the company is
kurumsal@enerjisauretim.com and the website of the company is
https://www.enerjisauretim.com.tr/[2].
b. OrganizationoftheCompany
Enerjisa √úretim Santralleri A.S.'s board of directors consists of 8 membersintotalunderthe
chairmanshipofAtillaKiss.TheboardisledbyaChairman,withKƒ±van√ßZaimlerservingasthe
Vice-Chairman, responsible for supporting and contributing to the company‚Äôs leadership in
strategic matters. The board comprises members representing both internal stakeholders
and external partners, such as Sabancƒ± Holding and E.ON, ensuring a balanced and diverse
oversight of the company‚Äôs interests [4]. The organization structureofthecompanyisshown
inFigure3.
Figure3.TheorganizationstructureofEnerjisa√úretimSantralleriA.S.[2].
Enerjisa √úretim Santralleri A.S. operates under a formal and hierarchical structure. The CEO
ƒ∞hsan Erbil Bay√ß√∂l oversees the entire organization, ensuring alignment with strategic
objectives,whiletheCFOMertYaycƒ±oƒülumanagesfinancialoperations,includingaccounting,
legal, treasury, and tax departments. The Commodity Risk ManagementDepartmentplaysa
critical role in mitigating financial risks related to energy trading, working closelywithother
departments to forecast market volatility. The Energy Markets Directorate manages power
trading, contract negotiation, and market analysis, ensuring the company remains
competitive in the energy markets. The organization structure of the company is shown in
Figure4.
This structure is primarily mechanistic, with clearly defined roles and centralized
decision-making. However, flexibility exists in departments such as Risk Management and
Market Analysis, which require adaptability to address market changes and risks. This
balance allows Enerjisa to maintain both operational efficiency and responsiveness in a
dynamic energy sector. Additionally, the company does not share a full organizational chart
fortheconfidentialityofdepartmentsandteams.
Figure4.TheorganizationstructureofEnerjisa√úretimSantralleriA.S.[2].
c. Production/ServiceSystem
Figure5.Production/ServiceSystemofEnerjisa√úretimA.S.[2].
5
The production and service system of Enerjisa √úretim A.S.iscenteredaroundtheMarketing
Clearing Price (MCP), which plays a critical role inregulatingthebalancebetweenelectricity
supply and demand. Figure 5 illustrates the relationships between the primary components
of Enerjisa √úretim A.S.'s production/service system. This system integrates several major
components, including production, marketing, finance, strategy, and advanced analytics.
These components are closely connected and work in unison to ensure the efficient
operation of the electricity market, with the MCP serving as the determining factor for
pricing electricity. The production aspect of the system involves multiple sources of energy
generation, such as hydroelectric, wind, solar, and thermal power plants. Energygeneration
from these sources is influenced by various external factorslikeweatherconditionsandfuel
prices. For instance, hydroelectric power generation relies heavily on climate and
meteorologicaldata,particularlyrainfallandwateravailability.Incontrast,thermalplantsare
dependentonthepricesoffuelssuchasnaturalgas,coal,andoil.Dispatchplaysakeyrolein
coordinating the energy output from these various sources and ensuring the balance
betweensupplyanddemand[5].
On the demand side, marketing is influenced by consumer behavior,whichfluctuatesbased
on factors such as holidays, weekends, and peak demand hours. Advanced Analytics is
employed to predict and model this consumer behavior, allowing marketingteamstoadjust
their strategies according to these forecasts. The interaction between the supply from the
production side and the demand forecasted by advanced analytics ultimately defines the
MCP, which in turn determines the price at which electricity is sold in the market. The
financial aspect of Enerjisa √úretim A.S. is critical to maintaining profitability and managing
risks. Finance teams focus on monitoring economic conditions and fuel prices to manage
costs effectively. They use portfolio optimization techniques toallocateresourcesefficiently,
ensuring that risks associated with price volatility and market fluctuations are minimized.
Risk management isintegraltothis,helpingtoanticipatepotentialdisruptionsinbothsupply
anddemandandtodevisestrategiesthatprotectagainstthoserisks[3].
Long-term planning is influenced by the company‚Äôs strategy, which includes mergers and
acquisitions aimed at expanding production capacity or optimizing existing infrastructure.
These strategicdecisionsimpacttheoverallsupplycapabilitiesofthecompany,aswellasthe
maintenance and technical reliability of the power plants. Maintenance and technical
problemsareamongthesupply-sidefactorsthatcanrestrictenergyproduction,affectingthe
ability to meet market demand. The flow of energy from production to the market can be
represented throughtheprocessofelectricitygeneration.Inthecaseofhydroelectricpower,
the process begins with climate data,suchasrainfallandwaterflowlevels,whichdetermine
the amount of energy that can be produced. Energy is then generated by the hydroelectric
power plants and transmitted through TEIAS transmission lines. However, transmission can
be limited by line restrictions or technical issues, which can reduce the overall supply of
electricity to the market. Once energy reaches the market, itspriceissetbasedontheMCP,
whichbalancesthegeneratedsupplywiththepredicteddemand[5][9].
In terms of productive and non-productive elements, the productive aspects of thisprocess
include the efficient use of renewable energy sources such as hydroelectric, wind,andsolar
power. These sources reduce dependence on fossil fuels, lowering costs and aligning with
sustainability goals.Advancedanalytics,whichimprovestheaccuracyofdemandforecasts,is
another productive element, ensuring that supply is closely matched with market demand.
On the other hand, non-productive elements include transmission line restrictions and
technical problems that hinder the delivery of generated energy, as well as maintenance
downtime,whichreducesoverallproductivityandincreasesoperationalcosts[2]

Enerjisa √úretim Santralleri A.S.'s board of directors consists of 8 membersintotalunderthe

sections.section_name:
The performance of this system relies heavily ontheaccurateforecastingofmarketdemand
and the effective coordination of energy dispatch. Enerjisa √úretim A.S. uses advanced
forecasting techniques, such as EPIAS MCP models, which analyze historical data and apply
predictive analytics to anticipate future market behavior. These forecasts are essential for
planning both short-term and long-term production strategies, helping to ensure that the
companycanmeetdemandwithoutoverproducingorunderproducingelectricity.Intermsof
logistics, the system must ensure the timely delivery of fuels to thermal power plants and
the smooth transmission of generated electricity to the grid. For thermal plants, logistics
involves managing fuel inventories, which must be procured in advance to avoid shortages
during periodsofhighdemand.Thisaspectoflogisticsiscrucialinmaintainingtheconsistent
operation of the plants and avoiding disruptions that could lead toalossofmarketshareor
revenue[2].
Consequently, the production and service system of Enerjisa √úretim A.S. is a highly
coordinated and data-driven process, where marketing, production, finance, and strategic
planning are closely intertwined. The use of advanced analytics, portfolio optimization, and
risk management ensures that the company can adapt to fluctuations in both supply and
demand, maintaining its position in the competitive energy market. Through accurate
forecasting and efficient logistics, the system achieves a balance between productivity and
cost-effectiveness,contributingtothecompany'slong-termsuccess.

d. ProfessionalandEthicalResponsibilitiesofEngineers
Engineers at Enerjisa √úretim Santralleri A.S. play a crucial role in ensuring the effective and
efficient operation of power plants, which are vital to the company‚Äôs mission of providing
reliable and sustainable energy. Their responsibilities encompass a wide range of
professional activities, including the design, operation, and maintenance of power
generation facilities. These activities are aimed at optimizing energy production processes
and ensuring that the power plants operate at peak efficiency while maintaining safety and
environmentalstandards[7].
Engineers are deeply involved in conducting technical analyses and simulations that
contribute to the improvement of power generation methods. This involves usingadvanced
modeling techniques and data analytics to assess plant performance, predict maintenance
needs, and implement technological upgrades. Their work is critical to the ongoing
optimization of plant operations, ensuring that Enerjisa remains competitive in theevolving
energy market. Moreover, engineers are responsible for integrating sustainability measures
into the company‚Äôs operations, reflecting Enerjisa‚Äôs commitment to reducing environmental
impacts. This involves implementing technologies and processes that enhance energy
efficiency, reduce emissions, and support the company‚Äôs broader environmental
objectives[7].
Compliance with safety regulations is another key aspect of the engineers‚Äô responsibilities.
They ensure that all operations adhere to national and international safety standards,
thereby protectingpublichealthandtheenvironment.Thiscommitmenttosafetyextendsto
the meticulous monitoring ofplantperformanceandtheproactivemanagementofpotential
risks. Engineers at Enerjisa also play anessentialroleinmanagingandanalyzingdatarelated
to plant operations, whichsupportsdecision-makingprocessesacrossthecompany.Through
performance monitoring and predictive maintenance, engineers contribute to minimizing
downtimeandenhancingtheoverallreliabilityofthepowerplants[7].
The professional and ethical responsibilities of engineers at Enerjisa √úretim are deeply
rooted in the company‚Äôs ethical standards and codes of conduct. Engineers are expected to
uphold integrity, accuracy, and transparency in all their work activities. This involves
7

presenting truthful and reliable information, avoiding any form of data manipulation, and
ensuring that all engineering decisions aremadeinthebestinterestsofthecompanyandits
stakeholders. The engineers‚Äô commitment to integrity is reflected in their adherence to the
highest standards of professional behavior, including the maintenance ofconfidentialityand
the avoidance of conflicts of interest. They are required to protect sensitive information
related to the company, its partners, and its operations, ensuring that such information is
used solely for authorized purposes and never disclosed without proper authorization.
Enerjisa √úretim‚Äôs ethical framework is governed by a comprehensive Code of Conduct that
outlines the professional and ethical standards expected of all employees, including
engineers. The company‚Äôs Code of Conduct emphasizes core values such as honesty,
accountability,andrespectforlawsandregulations.Specificpolicies,includingtheConflictof
Interest Policy and the Confidentiality Policy, are designed to guide employees in navigating
ethical dilemmas and maintaining professional integrity. The ethical code also includes
provisions for ensuring a fair working environment, promoting respect among colleagues,
andupholdingtheprinciplesofnon-discriminationandequalopportunity[7].
These professional and ethical standards are integral to the culture at Enerjisa √úretim and
are reinforced through ongoing training and awarenessprograms.Engineersareencouraged
to continuously improve their skills and stay updated with the latest advancements in their
field, ensuring that their work remains aligned with the company‚Äôs goals of operational
excellence and sustainability. The observed professional activities at Enerjisa demonstrate
that engineers are expected to upholdtheseethicalstandardsrigorously,contributingtothe
company‚Äôsreputationforintegrity,safety,andresponsibleengineeringpractices[7].

2. Summer Practice Description
During the summer practice, a series of detailed activities were carried out,focusingonthe
analysis and optimization of the Turkish electricity market. The primary task involved
extensive data retrieval and analysis using advanced technicaltoolsandmethodologies.The
hourly electricity price and demand data were collected from the EPIAS Transparency
Platform, providing the foundational dataset for the optimization models. This data was
processed and analyzed using Python and various data analysis libraries, including Pandas,
NumPy, Matplotlib, and Statsmodels. These tools wereinstrumentalinperformingstatistical
analyses, calculating descriptive statistics, detecting outliers, and exploring trends and
seasonality within the data series. The results from these analyses helped in understanding
themarketdynamicsandidentifyingkeyfactorsthatinfluenceelectricitypricesanddemand.
Optimization models were developed using Python‚Äôs Pulp library, which facilitated the
creation of mathematical models to optimize the generation schedules of power plants.
These models incorporated various constraints, such as operational limits of the plants,
market conditions, and regulatory requirements. The implementation of these constraints
allowed the simulation of realistic scenarios, ensuring that the generation profiles were not
only optimal but alsofeasibleundergivenconditions.ThePulplibrarywasparticularlyuseful
in formulating linear and mixed-integer programming problems, which were essential for
maximizing asset value byaligninggenerationscheduleswithmarketprices.SQL-basedtasks
were also a significant component oftheinternship,involvingdataextraction,manipulation,
and analysis to support decision-making processes. SQL was used to manage large datasets
efficiently, perform complex queries, and aggregate data to derive insightsthatwerecritical
for optimizing power generation. The integration of SQL with Pythonallowedforaseamless
flow of data between analysis and modeling, enhancing the accuracy and reliability of the
optimizationoutcomes.
8

The tasks performed were closely relatedtoDataAnalyticsEngineering,astheyinvolvedthe
application of engineering principles in data analysis, optimization modeling, and process
improvement.Theworkwasdirectlylinkedtothecoresubjectsofthemajor,suchassystems
analysis, operations research, and data management, providing a practical context for
theoretical knowledge acquired during academic studies. The experience of applying these
concepts to real-world problems in the energy sector made the work both interesting and
challenging. The opportunity to work with actual market data and develop models that
reflect the complexities of energy production scheduling was particularly engaging, as it
required critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Throughout the internship, significant
learning and professional growth were achieved. The use of advanced analytical tools
provided a deeper understanding of data-driven decision-making processes in engineering.
The practical application of optimization models enhanced the ability to design effective
solutions for complex engineering problems, reinforcing the importance of integrating data
analysis with optimization techniques. Additionally, the experience with SQL improved
database management skills, which are essentialforhandlinglarge-scaledatainengineering
projects.
As a result, the summer practice offered a comprehensive learning experience that bridged
the gap between academic studies and industry applications. The tasks performed not only
deepened the understanding of electricity market dynamics but also developed technical
competencies that are highly relevant to Data Analytics Engineering. The internship
experience underscored theimportanceofanalyticalandoptimizationskillsinmanagingand
optimizing energy generation, providing valuable insights intotheprofessionalandtechnical
demands of the field. The combination of technical skills, problem-solving abilities, and
industry exposure gained during the summer practice will be instrumental in future
engineeringendeavors.

2.1.TurkishElectricityMarket
Electricity generation can be carried out by private electricity generation companies that
hold a production license, as well as by public institutions. TEIAS is responsible for the
activities, maintenance, and repair of the electricity transmission network. In addition, it
operates the electricity balancing market and the ancillary services market. Both private
companies and public institutions can engage in wholesale activities. EUAS functions as a
publicinstitutionconductingwholesaleelectricitysalestomarketparticipants[5][9].
The electricity distribution networks are defined as thetransmissionofelectricityovershort
distances (at low and medium voltage) below 36 kW. Since 2013,thedistributionsectorhas
been composed of 21 privatized distributionregions.Privatedistributioncompaniesoperate
in accordance with their contracts with TEDAS, the public company responsible for
distribution. Retail activities refer to the sale of electricity to end consumers. Licensed
companies can sell electricity to users without the restrictions of a specific distribution
region. Obligated supply companies are required toprovideelectricitytoconsumerswhodo
not exercise their right as free consumers, based on a national tariff. Consumers exceeding
thefreeconsumerlimit(1,000kWh)havetherighttochoosetheirsupplier[5][9].
The Market Operator, known as the Istanbul Energy Exchange (EPIAS), is responsible for
managing day-ahead, intra-day, forward electricity transactions, as well as spotandforward
natural gas transactions, and balancing markets domestically. Since March 18, 2015, EPIAS
has managed free consumers in spot markets. Additionally, EPIAS oversees operations
related to renewable energy through systems like YEK-G and YEKDEM. Furthermore, EPIAS
provides comprehensive, real-time data for electricity and natural gas markets through the
9

Transparency Platform, ensuring transparency and equal access to information for market
participants[5]. Various government agencies responsible for regulating and operating the
electricitymarketareshowninFigure6[6][9].
Figure6.TheElectricityMarketValueChainandOperations[5].

2.1.1.MarketClearingPrices(MCP)&RealTimeConsumption
The necessary data were retrieved via REST API from the EPIAS Transparency Platform.
Hourly electricity prices (Market Clearing Prices - MCP) between January 1, 2021, and
December 31, 2023, were obtained from the day-ahead market link provided by EPIAS.
Additionally, hourly electricity demand data (Real-Time Consumption) for the same period
were sourced from the EPIASplatform.IncaseswheredataretrievalviaAPIwaschallenging,
the data were alternatively downloaded in Excel format. Python was used as the
programming language, utilizing libraries such as Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, and
Statsmodelsfortheanalysis.
Descriptive statistics were calculated for the hourly electricity demand in megawatt-hours
(MWh). Key statistical metrics, including minimum, median, mean, maximum, standard
deviation, variance, skewness, kurtosis, and the 25th and 75th percentiles, were obtained.
Outliers in the time series data were detected using the Interquartile Range (IQR) method.
Specifically, the bounds were setas1.5timestheIQRbelowthefirstquartile(Q1)andabove
the third quartile (Q3). Observations fallingoutsidetheseboundswereidentifiedasoutliers.
Additionally, Z-scores were used to detect extreme values beyondthreestandarddeviations
fromthemean.
Figure 7 illustrates theseasonaldecompositionofhourlyMarketClearingPrices(MCP)inthe
Turkish Electricity Market, highlighting the trend, seasonal, and residual components
observed between 2021 and 2023. The time series exhibited trends and seasonality, which
were explored using seasonal decomposition. The decomposition was performed using the
additive model in the Statsmodels library, revealing components such as trend, seasonality,
and residuals. The price series showed seasonal variations corresponding tomonthlycycles,
reflectingfluctuationsthatalignedwiththepricecapsetforeachmonth.

The optimization model was formulated to determine the optimal hourly generation
schedule that maximizes the asset value of the power plants in the portfolio. This problem
can be classifiedasaMixed-IntegerLinearProgramming(MILP)problemduetotheinclusion
ofintegerconstraints,suchastheminimumoperatinghoursforcoalpowerplants,combined
with linear relationships between variables. The objective of the model, as represented by
equation (1), was to maximize the total asset value by summing the generation outputs
across all power plants and time intervals. Equation (2) defined the requirement that the
total electricity generation from all power plants at each hour must meet thefixeddemand
of 1500 MW. This constraint ensured that supply matched the hourly demand throughout
the entire period. Equation (3) imposed a restriction on the hydroelectric power plants,
limiting their operation to a maximum of 80 hours perweek.Thisconstraintwasspecifically
applied to the hydroelectric plants (A and E) to account for their operational limitations.
Equation (4) ensured that the energy produced by each power plant did not exceed its
maximum capacity, linking the generation output to the plant‚Äôs capacity and operational
status. Equation (5) required each power plant to generate electricity above its minimum
generation level whenever it was in operation. This constraint ensured that all plants
operatedefficientlywithintheirminimumandmaximumthresholds.
Additional constraints were applied to the coal power plant (B) as represented inequations
(6), (7), and (8). Equation (6) required the coal power plant to operate for at least 12
consecutive hours once it was started, reflecting its operational constraints. Equation (7)
managed the dynamicbehaviorofthecoalpowerplant,controllingitsstartupandshutdown
states over time. Equation (8) ensured that if the coal power plant was started, it would
remain operational for a minimum of 12 hours,therebyenforcingtheconsecutiveoperation
requirement. The variables used in these equations included the energy produced by each
power plant at a given time, the capacity of each plant, and binary variables indicating
whether a plant was operating, starting up, or shutting down at any given hour. This
comprehensive formulation accurately captured the operational constraints of the power
plants while optimizing the overall asset value.ThemodelwasimplementedinPythonusing
the Pulp library, effectively optimizing the generation schedule under the defined
constraints.
13

Figure10.ConstraintsAppliedintheOptimizationModelforPowerPlantGeneration
Scheduling.
The dataset used in the optimization model was sourced from the EPIAS Transparency
Platform, which provides hourly electricity prices, known as Market Clearing Prices (MCP).
This dataset as shown in Figure 10 was then converted into a PandasDataFrame(plant_df),
which servedastheprimaryinputfortheoptimizationmodel.Theoptimizationproblemwas
defined using the pulp.LpProblem function, with the objective of maximizing asset value,
which was labeled as "Maximize_Asset_Value." Two sets of decision variables were
introduced: generation and is_operating. The generation variable was continuous and
represented the amount of electricity generated by each power plant for each hour, while
the is_operating variable was binary, indicating whether a power plant was operational
during a given hour. The objective function was constructed to maximize the asset value,
calculated as the difference between the Market Clearing Price (MCP) and the production
cost, multiplied by the generated electricity. This was implemented using the pulp.lpSum
function, which summed the contributions of each power plant across all hours. Themodel
demonstrated the practical application of mixed-integer linear programming (MILP)
techniques in optimizing power plant scheduling, effectively balancing operational
constraintswitheconomicobjectives.

2.2.SQLCaseStudy
A database is created using data generated randomly under specific rules. This database is
manipulatedusingsqlite3library tocontrolcertainfeatures.
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language that used to interact with
databases. It is a standard language for managing and manipulating relational database
management systems (RDBMS). SQL allows users to perform different operations such as
creating, updating, modifying, and deleting data within a database which works with data
organized into tables. This structure enables users to easily retrieve the information they
need through queries. It consists of several types of commands and each of them designed
for specific operations on the data.DataDefinitionLanguage(DDL)isusedtodefine,modify,
or delete database structures. Data Manipulation Language (DML) allows users to
manipulate data within tables. It enables actions likeadding,updating,orremovingrecords.
Transaction Control Language (TCL) provides managed transactions to ensure data integrity
during operations. It allows control over how changes are applied or reverted. The Data
Query Language (DQL) is focused on retrieving specific information from the database.
Moreover, Data Control Language (DCL) isusedtomanagepermissionsandcontrolaccessto
thedatabase.ThestructurednatureofSQLwiththecommandsisshowninFigure12[8].
Figure12.StructuredSQLCommands[8].

SQLite is a lightweight, serverless, and self-contained database engine, meaning it does not
require installation or configuration. The sqlite3 module provides the necessary tools to
create,manage,andinteractwithSQLitedatabaseswithinPythonprograms[10].
